funder.name: Fonds De La Recherche Scientifique - FNRS

abstract: <jats:p>The Iberian Peninsula is a global hotspot for bee diversity due to its large number of different habitats, particularly Mediterranean scrubland, mountains, and hot and cold steppe. In line with its status as a hotspot of bee diversity, the peninsula hosts a very large <jats:italic>Andrena</jats:italic> fauna, which despite progress in recent years remains incompletely studied, particularly with reference to genetic investigation. Here the Iberian <jats:italic>Andrena</jats:italic> fauna is comprehensively revised, resulting in a total of 228 recorded species. Numerous taxonomic changes are necessary following inspection of museum specimens, type material, and genetic investigation. The following subgenera are described: <jats:italic>Pruinosandrena</jats:italic><jats:bold>subgen. nov.</jats:bold>, containing six taxa previously placed in the subgenus Campylogaster Dours, 1873, and <jats:italic>Blandandrena</jats:italic><jats:bold>subgen. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>Bryandrena</jats:italic><jats:bold>subgen. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>Limbandrena</jats:italic><jats:bold>subgen. nov.</jats:bold>, and <jats:italic>Ovandrena</jats:italic><jats:bold>subgen. nov.</jats:bold>, containing one, one, one, and four taxa previously placed in the subgenus Poliandrena Warncke, 1968. Andrena (Limbandrena) toelgiana Friese, 1921 <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> is synonymised with A. (Limbandrena) limbata Eversmann, 1852. The current lectotype of A. (Micrandrena) obsoleta Pérez, 1895 was incorrectly designated by Warncke; the taxon differs from <jats:italic>A. obsoleta</jats:italic> sensu Warncke, belonging instead to a taxon within the <jats:italic>A. mariana</jats:italic> Warncke, 1968 complex. A new lectotype is designated for <jats:italic>A. obsoleta</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. resurr.</jats:bold> from Algeria, and <jats:italic>A. mariana solda</jats:italic> Warncke, 1974 <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> is synonymised with it; A. (Micrandrena) alma Warncke, 1975 <jats:bold>stat. nov.</jats:bold>, A. (Micrandrena) mica Warncke, 1974 <jats:bold>stat. nov.</jats:bold>, and A. (Micrandrena) tenostra Warncke, 1975 <jats:bold>stat. nov.</jats:bold> are raised to species status. Andrena (Truncandrena) abunda Warncke, 1974 <jats:bold>stat. nov.</jats:bold>, A. (Micrandrena) lecana Warncke, 1975 <jats:bold>stat. nov.</jats:bold>, A. (Pruinosandrena) parata Warncke, 1967 <jats:bold>stat. nov.</jats:bold>, A. (Micrandrena) pauxilla Stöckhert, 1935 <jats:bold>sp. resurr.</jats:bold>, A. (Pruinosandrena) succinea Dours, 1872 <jats:bold>sp. resurr.</jats:bold>, and A. (Notandrena) varuga Warncke, 1975 <jats:bold>stat. nov.</jats:bold> are also returned or elevated to species status. A lectotype is designated for A. (Euandrena) lavandulae Pérez, 1902 <jats:bold>sp. resurr.</jats:bold> which is returned to species status, and A. (Euandrena) impressa Warncke, 1967 <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> is synonymised with it. Andrena (Truncandrena) nigropilosa Warncke, 1967 <jats:bold>stat. nov.</jats:bold> is elevated to species status, and A. (Truncandrena) truncatilabris espanola Warncke, 1967 <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> is synonymised with it as a junior subjective synonym. A lectotype is designated for A. (Melandrena) vachali Pérez, 1895; A. (Melandrena) creberrima Pérez, 1895 <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> and A. (Melandrena) vachali<jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> are synonymised with A. (Melandrena) discors Erichson, 1841, and Andrena (Melandrena) hispania Warncke, 1967 <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> is synonymised with A. (Melandrena) morio Brullé, 1832. Andrena (Pruinosandrena) mayeti Pérez, 1895 <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> is newly synonymised with A. (Pruinosandrena) caroli Pérez, 1895 and <jats:italic>A.</jats:italic> (incertae sedis) <jats:italic>setosa</jats:italic> Pérez, 1903 <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> is newly synonymised with <jats:italic>A.</jats:italic> (incertae sedis) <jats:italic>ranunculorum</jats:italic> Morawitz, 1877. Andrena (Simandrena) cilissaeformis Pérez, 1895 <jats:bold>sp. resurr.</jats:bold> is returned to species status, and is the correct name for A. (Simandrena) breviscopa auctorum. <jats:italic>Andrena</jats:italic> (incertae sedis) <jats:italic>breviscopa</jats:italic> Pérez, 1895 is returned to synonymy with <jats:italic>A.</jats:italic> (incertae sedis) <jats:italic>numida</jats:italic> Lepeletier, 1841, and <jats:italic>A.</jats:italic> (incertae sedis) <jats:italic>inconspicua</jats:italic> Morawitz, 1871 is newly synonymised <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> with <jats:italic>A. numida</jats:italic>. Andrena (Euandrena) isolata<jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> and A. (Micrandrena) ortizi<jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> are described from the Sierra Nevada (Granada), A. (Truncandrena) ghisbaini<jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> is described from Málaga province, and A. (Avandrena) juliae<jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> is described from Cádiz province. The males of A. (Micrandrena) alma and <jats:italic>A.</jats:italic> (?<jats:italic>Euandrena</jats:italic>) <jats:italic>ramosa</jats:italic> Wood, 2022 are described. Additional lectotypes are designated for A. (Plastandrena) asperrima Pérez, 1895, A. (Plastandrena) atricapilla Pérez, 1895, A. (Aenandrena) hystrix Schmiedeknecht, 1883, A. (Pruinosandrena) lanuginosa Spinola, 1843, A. (Notandrena) ranunculi Schmiedeknecht, 1883, and A. (Euandrena) symphyti Schmiedeknecht, 1883. Neotypes are designated for A. (Chlorandrena) boyerella Dours, 1872, A. (Notandrena) griseobalteata Dours, 1872, A. (Taeniandrena) poupillieri Dours, 1872, A. (Pruinosandrena) succinea Dours, 1872, and <jats:italic>A.</jats:italic> (incertae sedis) <jats:italic>numida</jats:italic> Lepeletier, 1841. Type photographs and diagnostic characters are presented in each case, as well as new dietary information for understudied species. Finally, an identification key is presented in order to facilitate future research on this hyper-diverse genus in one of their global diversity hotspots, and current and future research perspectives for Iberian <jats:italic>Andrena</jats:italic> are discussed.</jats:p>
title: ﻿The genus Andrena Fabricius, 1775 in the Iberian Peninsula (Hymenoptera, Andrenidae)
